Award.AwardTitle: Student Travel Support for the 2017 International Conference on Architecture Support for Programming Languages and Operating Systems (ASPLOS)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal is for support of a travel to the 22nd ACM International Conference on Architectural Support for Programming Languages and Operating Systems (ASPLOS), to be held in Xi'an, China, April 8-12, 2017. ASPLOS is a premier forum for multidisciplinary systems research spanning computer architecture and hardware, programming languages and compilers, and operating systems. Papers in ASPLOS may target diverse goals such as performance, energy and thermal efficiency, resiliency, security, and sustainability. The proposal requests travel support funds to enable students to defray the costs of traveling to and attending ASPLOS-22. The funds requested from NSF will help support a large number of students who are expected to attend ASPLOS, including those who are not ACM members. Priority will be given to students that are US citizens and permanent residents, as well as to students belonging to under-represented groups.

The importance of forum such as ASPLOS continues to grow as we come to the end of Moore's Law, experience the explosion of big data, scales ranging from ultra-low power wearable devices to exascale parallel and cloud computers, and the need for sustainability, and increasingly human-centered applications. ASPLOS embraces systems research that directly targets these new problems in new ways. Historically, the conference has attracted top research papers from both academia and industry, and many innovations published in the proceedings have been influential in the history of the processor industry. The acceptance rates for submitted papers is typically between 15-20%.

POR.DRECONTENT:
ASPLOS is the premier forum for multidisciplinary systems research spanning computer architecture and hardware, programming languages and compilers, operating systems and networking, as well as applications and user interfaces. The research may target diverse goals such as performance, energy and thermal efficiency, resiliency, security, and sustainability. The importance of such cross-cutting research continues to grow as we grapple with the end of Dennard scaling, the explosion of big data, scales ranging from ultra-low power wearable devices to exascale parallel and cloud computers, the need for sustainability, and increasingly human-centered applications. ASPLOS embraces systems research that directly targets these new problems in new ways.

The purpose of this award is to support student travel to ASPLOS 2018.  Such travel enriches the conference, exposes students to the latest scientific findings in the field, and helps educate the next generation of scholars and practitioners in the field.  It also provides support for under-represented groups to attend the conference. 

Approximately 57 students from around the world applied for a student travel grant to ASPLOS.  All eligible students were provided some support to attend the conference.  The award from the National Science Foundation supported the partial or all travel costs of 19 US citizens and other students.  Among these students, at least 10% are hispanic, 25% are women. Some students did not report their ethnicity so these percentages may be underestimated.  

 

Support from this award gave students the opportunity to attend ASPLOS and network with other participants. This is an invaluable opportunity to learn about the latest research, tools, and methodologies in the design of new computer architectures and systems.  It also gave them an opportunity to network with their peers at other institutions and access to the best minds in the field.  These opportunities are critical for improving their research, finding collaborators, and making connections that will secure future employment or educational opportunities.

With the support from NSF, the students are able to attend ASPLOS and present their research results. The presentations are attended by international researchers from broader community. Therefore, the research results are well deiseminated to the communities of interests. 

These students will likely seek employment at US corporations, universities, and government research labs. Hence, the travel awards made possible by this grant helps contribute to the creation and retention of a highly trained, diverse, and capable IT work force which is critical for continued economic growth.
